ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: All the basics on computer graphics. To general topics and where they can go.
Image editing, mesh editing, raytracing, and rasterizing. Color theory and lighting models. A good amount of web (JS) development for the final project.
basic knowledge of compiter graphics

You learn a variety of topics in the field of computer graphics in breadth, specially 2D images, 3D models, rendering, and animation. I think this class should be renamed to "intro to computer graphics." It's really really fun learning about these topics, and especially if you use apps like Unity, Unreal Engine, Blender, Autodesk, etc or even Instagram filters! If you use them or try to learn them, you'll get better at them after taking this class, understanding what each tool is and how it works underneath. You also code in javascript a lot, so you'll get practices in a web programming language like js.
I learned all about the basics of computer graphics including some more complex approaches and methods.

Linear algebra, multivariable calculus, matrix math, vector math. 2D image representation and processing, 3D model representation and editing, rendering, rasterization, animation methods. Homework uses Javascript and WebGL and GLSL.
Concepts relating to computer graphics. Basics of image processing, 3D modeling and rendering.
Graphics generation, rendering and animation techniques in js and THREEjs.
WebGL, ThreeJS, JavaScript; Ray Tracing, Graphics pipeline
Image processing, Modeling, Rendering, Graphics pipeline
Knowledge in manipulating graphics, modeling 3D objects, rendering objects with light, etc.
basics of computer graphics, a better understanding of the technical/ mathematical work behind-the-scenes to make computer generate graphics look realistic.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There were too many assignments. I'm really happy they cut the last one. 9 am classes are also so hard to get to.
the lectures were a little bit dry, would be better if the lectures could be made more engaging

The strengths were that it was taught well, and the assignments were very clear. Although, a weakness would be the minimal support when it came to debugging assignments which could prove to be tedious at times.

Professor Dorsey is encouraging and willing to answer students' questions. She is also very understanding and willing to record the lecture when a student had to miss class for a family reasons. The TA Alvin is very supportive and patient and willing to explain anything students are struggling with. Lectures are very interesting because they show the real-life applications of concepts and the professor and TA are willing to stay after class to clarify stuff. The class is well-organized, instructions are detailed and well-communicated. Collaboration with a partner was encouraged for some assignments, which was very helpful. The time allotted for each assignment was reasonable, 1-2 weeks, so not too stressful. Each assignment has an extra credit art contest, it's exciting and creative and makes the pset more enjoyable, and you can look at other students' entries in the art gallery. Professor Dorsey provided a study guide for each exam, which corresponded pretty well to the actual exam content, so you know what is important to study.

The course content is very interesting, and I was engaged throughout the class. However, the difficulty across different weeks feels a bit ineven, and the assignments were frustrating. Frustrating not because it's conceptually hard, but because the assignment itself is vaguely worded and the provided code unclear, meaning that I spent most of my time trying to understand what exactly the assignment is asking for instead of actually applying concepts learned  in class.

The class was basically off the princeton course. The psets are also the exact same, but still pretty enjoyable. I think graphics coding in javascript is nice, but definitely not industry standard, and using c++ would be align better with yale cs.
Too much crammed into one semester, all really interesting but too fast paced. The psets took forever to complete but were only worthy 5% of the grade.
A lot of range (a good taste of everything)

Great class in terms of content. The PSETs are the main way through which students learn, and it shows with how much time they take. That said, they are worth far too little for how much time we put into them, as compared to the "quizzes" which are 50% of the class (2x 25%) and take 50 minutes each.

The pacing of the course is quite good. It's manageable to keep up with each concept as it's introduced.
The slides can be improved. May times when reviewing a lecture it's not clear from the slides what different terms mean.
Also, the programming assignments can have better code comments for the skeleton code, to understand what the arguments for each function are.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if they're not taking other hard classes.
Yes. A thorough and gentle introduction to computer graphics and game development.
yes

100000000%. Again, if you are doing / interested in doing Unity, Blender, Unreal, Autodesk etc, or want to understand how modern video games / movies / VR / etc look so nice. You'll have a lot of FUN taking this class. Plus the class codes in js so it's much easier than C. Plus plus plus, all projects are partner projects starting from assignment 3, and the final project is a group projects where you work together and make a video game of your imagination! Plus the class structure is immensely beneficial as stated earlier. etc etc. Please please please take this class if you are a gamer into game design, an artist into movie making, or much more.

If you are interested in Computer Graphics, this is the only course that will teach you about it. So in that sense, yes you should take it. I think the experience could be a lot better with a little more administrative help, such as hiring ULAs (there was only 1.5 hours of office hours per week for ~25 people), and more consistent Ed responses (about half of people's posts on there were never responded to, which was really disappointing). As it stands, the course this semester basically amounted to a lot of self-teaching to get through the assignments. Prof. Dorsey is very kind and helpful when you speak to her individually, but she just seemed a little bit lethargic or perhaps overwhelmed as an administrator of the course.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student due to how fundamental it is in teaching basic computer graphics.
Yes

Yes, I would recommend this course to someone who's interested in the topic of computer graphics and who is just getting started. The class does not go into great depth on any one topic in computer graphics, but gives a good bird's eye view of the world of computer graphics as a whole. But whoever takes this class should know that the assignments are very much time sinks.
I know this class is probably better taught by Professor Kim, but I would still take it with Dorsey if you have no other option
yes if youre interested in going into graphics
Yes - it covers a lot of anything you might be interested in when it comes to graphics. It is a good place to start and will help you figure out which topics you'd be interested in exploring further
Yes yes yes! If you are interested in computer graphics, this is a wonderful survey course of the different topics of the field. That said, be prepared to put in the work for the PSETs.
yes. It's very interesting and the practical assignments and project help you learn a new language (ThreeJS).
